Jesus did not seek the praise of others, yet his actions could not be hidden, as the truth of the miraculous resurrection was undeniable. People needed to be convinced that this incredible event had truly taken place.

Philip Schaff: And the fame hereof, lit, ‘this fame,’ or ‘report,’ went forth into all that land.
Many who had seen the girl dead, must afterwards have seen her alive.
John Gill: He not affecting the applause of men.
It was not possible the thing should be entirely concealed.
They must be persuaded of the miracle.

Jesus did not seek the praise of others, yet his actions could not be hidden, as the truth of the miraculous resurrection was undeniable. The report of this extraordinary event quickly spread throughout the entire region, capturing the attention of all who heard it. It is likely that many who had witnessed the girl's lifeless body firsthand were now witnesses to her restored vitality. Jesus did not seek to bask in the admiration of others, but the sheer impossibility of keeping this miraculous occurrence entirely secret made it undeniable to the people. The incredulous onlookers needed convincing that this wondrous miracle had indeed occurred.

Convincing the skeptical observers was crucial in affirming the reality of this extraordinary miracle.
